Award.AwardTitle: CRII: III: Spatio-Temporal Data Mining to Learn From Unlabeled Climate Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global climate change and its potential societal impacts have become one of our era's greatest challenges. Climate science is experiencing tremendous data growth (~100s of exabytes by 2020), yet our ability to learn from such data is limited because most of the existing data science methods are not well-suited for the noisy, heterogeneous, incomplete, and spatio-temporal data in climate science. This project will develop novel data mining methods to enhance our ability to learn from large and complex datasets with scientific and societal importance.

Specifically, this project will focus on foundational advances to traditional pattern mining by incorporating information from multiple uncertain and incomplete datasets to discover statistically significant patterns in continuous data with an application to oceanography. We propose the notion of "spatio-temporal redundancy" where patterns are discovered in multiple related datasets to offset the lack of target labels in the data. This approach will address two major challenges in Big Data analysis for scientific discovery. First, as the size and complexity of the data grow, the likelihood of false discoveries increases significantly. Second the lack of ground truth verification data makes objective validation a challenge. Finally, we rely on First Principles and domain theory to constrain our data mining approaches to produce tractable and scientifically consistent results. These methods can generalize to various domains where no ground truth data are available but one has access to several information-rich, yet uncertain datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on developing a new suite of data mining methods to effectively and accurately analyze large complex space-time datasets such as measurements from earth-orbiting satellites. While data science has recently seen tremendous advances (e.g. self-driving cars, etc.) the majority of gains have occurred outside of science and specifically in domains that rely on space-time data.??Our project focuses specifically on what’s known as “unsupervised machine learning” where we do not have explicit examples to use to teach an algorithm. The unsupervised nature of this work further complicates scientific discovery. Our project proposed a new approach called spatio-temporal consistency that shows that in the absence of examples (or better known as “labels”) we can use multiple spatio-temporal datasets (e.g. temperature, rainfall, etc.) over the same region to identify unlabeled objects better than with any single dataset alone.??Using these techniques, we were able to monitor millions of vortices in the ocean, known as ocean eddies, that are critical for our planet’s energy distribution. This work led to the creation of the largest open-source ocean eddies dataset for others to us (http://datadryad.org/resource/doi:10.5061/dryad.gp40h) as well as a set of computational tools to identify ocean eddies in satellite altimetry data (https://github.com/jfaghm/OceanEddies). Finally, we have expanded these methods to be applied to other domains outside of oceanography that have similar data challenges such as global health (https://ghatlas.io/)

The funding from this project supported two PhD students from under-represented backgrounds and contributed to their professional development by attending and presenting at conferences and workshops. Furthermore, we hosted two undergraduate students from under-represented background to perform research over the summer.
